text_clean_combined: Good morning, Mayor Willett.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Good morning.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: So I understand that you're the Mayor of Coutts, Alberta.

speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And you have been a resident of Coutts since 2013?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That is correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And a councillor for the past five years?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And Mayor for four years now?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And you had an interview with me and my colleagues on September 6th of this year? Do you remember that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes, I do.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And you remember seeing a summary of your interview?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: I do.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: So if we could just pull up WTS00000012. So this is going to be a summary of that interview. You had an opportunity to review this summary; correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: I did, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And I understand that you have a clarification to your summary this morning?

speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: I do. Actually, there was a police presence growing all the time in the village. It didn't go from 6 to 50 in one day, three days into the protests.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yes. So I'll bring you to that passage just so that we can confirm. So the second page, and it's the fourth paragraph down. Then you say: "On February 1...an additional 42 RCMP vehicles arrived at the border..." And what you're saying is that between those dates there was a gradual build up?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: There was a build up, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Perfect. Thank you. So we're going to put that summary into evidence. Now, I understand, Mr. Mayor, that you live about four blocks from the border and three blocks from where the protest was occurring. Is that about right?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah, that's correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And while these events were happening, would it be fair to say that you attended the location or went to look what was going on on a fairly regular basis?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That's correct, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: The last census had us at 224.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And I understand that the village's amenities include a convenience store, a restaurant, a bank, but that a number of the other services that residents would use would be found in Milk River. Is that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That is correct. All of the major things that you take for granted in a larger community we have to go to Milk River for, doctor, pharmacy, dentist, hardware store, any of that kind of thing, grocery store.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And Milk River is about 18 kilometres away?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Eighteen K.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Sounds good. So if we could just pull up COM924. This is a map of Coutts and the surrounding area. We looked at a similar map yesterday with one of the other witnesses, and so I won't go into detail on this. But if we can just go to page 5, and if we could -- yeah, that works. So my understanding is that the blockade formed around the point identified as Checkpoint 4?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: That's correct. And Smuggler Saloon, which we'll talk about a little bit today, that is a local establishment, and that's identified here on the map as well?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And that's where a number of protesters regularly met?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes, it became a gathering spot, yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Perfect. And so my understanding is that the blockade that occurred was on Highway 4. Is that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And that highway connects Coutts and Milk River?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That's our connection, yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: When -- and I know things may have fluctuated during this period, but when the blockade was blocking both lanes of traffic was it preventing Coutts residents from travelling to Milk River?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes, it was.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And would it have also been preventing traffic flow from the border, coming out from the border?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Well, a lot of it, yes. Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And any traffic south to the border?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. Now, I also understand that there was some kind of route, and I'm hoping you can explain this to us some kind of alternative route available through what I think you referred to as Patty Joe's field or something like that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: It was actually her yard. The -- I wasn't there when all of this part of the world was developed, but when the highway was turned into a four-lane major thoroughfare, things changed. An access road runs along to the south of that highway and ends at a farm there. A local family rented the farm. Then they continued their road around their house, and it connected to the street, to -- I forget what that is, Fourth Street I think, in Coutts. And with permission ordinarily, you'd let Patty Joe know that you wanted to take a load of whatever that way to miss the scales. Can I say that? That you were going to be going through her yard, and you'd drive through their yard and that was an alternate route, as it were. It suddenly began carrying a whole lot of traffic. And they got -- it got to the point where they couldn't use their home really.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And so how is that route being during January and February of this year, when there was a full blockade on the highway, what did it allow traffic to do?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Well, it allowed you to miss the blockade and you could go up to -- close to the rail crossing. I don't have -- there's a county road there and it goes out onto the highway just at the rail crossing, around the curve from what we're looking at here. And so it allowed people to drive through there and miss the blockade and go on up to Milk River.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And so would it allow traffic coming from the border to circumvent the blockade and go all the way up to Milk River?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: It would have except it's not really a truck route, and if somebody came in driving, there's no reason that they couldn't have cut through Coutts and then through Patty Joe's place, but you'd have to know. If you're a local, you know. And, yeah, that -- you could get around, yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And I assume the same is true for any Coutts residents trying to get to Milk River, they could have also ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Oh, yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: --- used that route had they known? Okay.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah, everybody knew it was there and you could go that way.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And are you aware of whether RCMP was redirecting any traffic through that route?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes, they did. We talked - - I talked with Curtis, Corporal Curtis Peters, who was my contact, and let him know about the road. He wanted to -- they made some communication. And what we wound up doing -- what they wound up doing was making a square. The ground was frozen and so they were able to run straight ahead from the street, make a right at the end of Patty Joe's property and go down that way, so you didn't have to go through her yard. And so it became an unofficial exit point. In fact, they took trucks through there later.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. Thank you very much. I understand that police services for the village are provided by the provincial division of the RCMP?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And the nearest detachment is in Milk River; correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And how many officers are posted there?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Four to five.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: I'd like to go to COU00000249. I understand that on January 4th, a protest organizer attended the village office to advise of the upcoming protest. Do you remember that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes, you'll see this is assigned Kelly. She's the assistant in the office to my CEO, and she received a phone call.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And during that phone call, how did the protester describe the anticipated protest?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: They were just giving us a heads up that they were going to be coming and doing a slow roll around the entrance to the country. And as you can see, it says that they won't be blocking any residents from using the entrance and exit.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: If we can go to COU00001515? So I understand from your witness statement that on social media, a little bit later around the 27th, I think you said, you saw a post suggesting there would be an attempt to block the border.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Is that correct? Is this the post that you saw?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes, it is.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And do you know where you saw this posting?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: It was on a bulletin board out of Lethbridge. My wife spotted a link on the Lethbridge and Area How are the Roads. It's a Facebook post that obviously gives traffic reports and there was a link there, and we followed that link to this particular document.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And so were you concerned at that time about the risk of a blockade occurring?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Very much so.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And why were you concerned, in particular for your residents? Can you tell us about why you were concerned?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: We had been slammed by snowbirds, of which if you don't live there, that may make no sense at all, but we -- the 18th of November, the U.S. changed the border crossings to allow fully vaccinated people to enter the States. And all of the people who ordinarily go south for the winter down to Arizona in their RVs and so on decided they had to be there at midnight in order to be the first to cross the border. And we wound up with the largest demonstration anybody down there had seen yet of truck blockages and so on. And we had a highway blockage that ran across the tracks and on off over the hill. And they came into the town and double parked everywhere, blocked both entrances to the village, so that in the event that we needed to get our firetruck out or something, we wouldn't have been able to do it. So we had experience with the blockage, and I had visions of what was going to happen here as well.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And my understanding is that wasn't a protest. That just a number of people trying to cross the border at the same time?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: I did a lot of protesting, but, no, it wasn't a protest.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you. I understand -- so if we can just pull up for reference COU183? I understand that on that same day, January 27th, you wrote to the Premier, Premier Kenney of Alberta and the Solicitor General, Sonya Savage, to advise them that you had heard about this risk of a blockade; correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And I understand someone called you the next day in response to this email?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes, I received a call from the Solicitor General's office. I do not know the name of the person. I remembered the name Pilgrim and nobody by that name has ever worked for the Government of Alberta that I can find, so I'm not sure who I spoke to. Anyway, saying to the effect that I had woken everybody up around -- that they had been in contact then with the police of all flavours, and they were going to -- RCMP's on top of it, and we got it under control, basically, is what I remember.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: So my understanding is that you observed on January 29th the convoy driving up to the border; correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah, me and everybody in town were out to see what was going on.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And can you maybe just tell us what you observed on that day?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Well, about what I had expected. I'd seen convoy demonstrations by other groups on television and online. A lot of trucks, a lot of signs, a lot of honking, and it was a convoy; a parade of vehicles from half- tons to -- no monster trucks but large tractor-trailers.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And that pinpoint, that checkpoint 4 that we looked at before on the map, that’s where you saw them begin to U-turn to head back towards Milk River?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah, that’s Highway 500, and it’s a major crossing point that goes -- comes up from over the tracks out of the -- to the east of the village, and then makes a crossing there with Highway 4. So it’s the first place that you could really make a U-turn, or the last place, I guess, if you’re coming from the north. It’s the last place you could make a U-turn, either there or the next exit, and it was smaller. So the RCMP, I think, had decided this was the best place to turn everybody around.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And my understanding from your witness statement is that about 45 minutes later, you observed that they had blocked that intersection where they were U-turning; is that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah, I think the RMCP told me 42 minutes, but it happened, yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And how many RCMP vehicles did you observe that day?

I thought that it had to do with cross-border truckers having their permissions removed. For two years they’d been travelling back and forth, exempt from vaccination requirements and so on, and just when things were starting to loosen up -- I mentioned the 18th, people are starting to go across, everybody’s getting more normal feel -- suddenly the federal governments in both Canada and the US decided that you no longer have an exemption, you’re going to have to be vaccinated, and I think that was the tipping point. So I thought everybody was coming for that purpose.

At that time, there were several different groups. It was mob rule, I guess, is -- I don’t like that expression, but that’s -- that’s the idea. There was nobody really able to just get everybody together and say, okay, we’re going to do this and everybody would go out and do it. And so that’s what was happening. I got that feeling, though, that because of what had happened that the mood in the crowd had changed and they were going to depart.

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: I did actually, yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

And it was mostly tractors. At that point there weren't a lot of trucks around. But anyway, they lined up down the street on the 14th, then I received the word they're going to go at 10, and at 10 o'clock they were gone. Well, they left.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

I talked so long I forgot the question.

What was your understanding of that? ] MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT: This is my understanding of that. I have no other -- we never talked about it otherwise.

speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Okay. So this text message is -- this text message is all you ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That’s it. Yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: --- all you have. Okay. Thank you. I understand that Mr. Evans told you about concerns he had with more extreme elements participating in the protest. Can you tell us about that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah. We had a meeting where we talked -- I talked for quite a bit, for 45 minutes or so. And one of the things I -- if you go back far enough in my history, bear with me, go back far enough in my history, I worked in mining in Northern Manitoba, was a steelworker, was a steelworker steward, went through wildcat strikes and so on. And there were always hardline guys, and then the guys that were there for a goodtime. You could have a wildcat strike and everybody is up and up and up and then it tapered off and you wound up with the core, and you might even find guys that you’d never seen before there. And we talked about how that was a danger and if something like this longer went on, the more the opportunity existed for outside elements to come in and cause disruption.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And he agreed with -- -
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: And he agreed with that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: He agreed with that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That was one of his concerns.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Did you yourself observe the nature of the protests changing over time?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: The mood changed. I talked about, somewhere, it being almost like a big community meeting of all the farmers in the area. And this was -- don’t kid yourself to think this is a big trucker protest. This is mostly a farm protest.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: I think you, in your witness statement, you say that about your meeting on February 4th?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And, you know, they had the kids there and it was just a family thing. As it went on, a lot of that attitude disappeared. Didn’t see a lot of kids playing hockey anymore. And just -- and if you follow their social media, they took a picture when it was all over, just before they left, which was handy for anybody investigating, but a picture of the whole group in front of Smuggler’s, and it wasn’t a large group at that time. It had gotten smaller. But to go back to my strike days, it’s the same thing. As -- the longer you do something like this and you go in expecting results right away and it doesn’t happen, the more disheartened you become, and then you start listening to other things about, well, if we only did this, this would happen, and so on. So it’s just -- it’s a typical demonstration. And while I didn’t have a crystal ball, if I had, it would have paid off, because what we feared seems to have happened.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Did you observe any violence or harassment during the protest?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Never did. No.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Did you yourself receive any threats?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yes. I got one death threat online. Facebook. Serious enough that the RCMP took it seriously. I’m not sure how good a threat it was, because it was sent from a personal page. But anyway. It was a death threat. And I received calls. Everybody gets phone calls. Just the phone and hang up, or phone and “You thought you wanted to be mayor, ha-ha.” You know? Like that kind of stuff. I had people out front taking pictures of my house and it was first time I’d done this, so it was a little nerve-racking.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Did you ever observe any weapons yourself around that time in Coutts?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: No, we didn’t. Some of the protestors were staying in the motel across the road from where I live, and we saw from time to time them moving heavy hockey bags, and my wife said, “It’s guns,” but we had no weapons that I ever witnessed.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Did you ever hear anything about efforts by protestors to dissuade tow truck drivers from assisting the RCMP?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Not directly. Social media, I saw what was going on. But I never directly talked to anyone.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Did you ever have any discussions with CBSA officials about the protest?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Never did. Other than see somebody at the post office or something. Some of them live there.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: I understand that the RCMP attended a village council meeting on February 8th, and in your summary you state that they described their response as “building the airplane while you’re flying it.” What did you understand those comments to be referring to?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Well just the way it sounds. As I said, we all got caught flatfooted. Nobody had expected this to happen. And the -- I’m not sure of his rank, but anyway, the answer to the question was, “We’re building the airplane as we’re flying it. We’re making it up as we go along. We’ve got tactics, and we’re trying them, and if they don’t work, we try something else until we find out how it works.” It was an education, I guess, for everyone.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you. In the short time we have left, I’d just like to talk about the impact on the village and its residents. In the summary, you say that the blockade greatly disrupted everyday life for Coutts residents. Could you maybe explain to us in what ways?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: I have done a mental survey and I think I had about a 70/30 split in the village, with 30 on my side and 70 supporting the protest, regardless of what it meant. The -- we still have neighbours that won’t talk to each other because of the protests. They didn’t -- they didn’t get out and -- we had a lot of collaborators -- not collaborators; sympathetic people in the village who figured it was our duty to feed everybody; if they need a room, give them a room. These are all good people and we should really look after them. As unneighbourly and heartless as it seems, my opinion was if you came down here and you blockaded the highway and now you’re not wanting to leave the protest, but you need your medication that you left at home, the road goes that way, go get your medication, instead of making a public scene about, “I don’t have my medicine, can you bring it to me?” “We don’t have food do,” you know? “You got food at home.” That what my answer to those kind of complaints. My neighbours being good, rural Alberta people figure somebody’s in need, you look after them regardless of how they got there, I guess. And there was a lot of sympathy over the -- and as I said, the driving force of the protest, the original cause had to do with cross-border vaccination and then it mutated into “My body, my rights, my...” -- you know, all of the different conspiracy things that were going on.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: How’s ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: And then people -- people didn’t let that go, and so it still exists to this day.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: How significantly did the protest interfere with residents’ ability to access services in Milk River?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Depending on the person, how comfortable they were with driving past monster pieces of equipment. I think we heard Marco yesterday talk about how one tractor is intimidating even if it’s sitting still, if you haven’t been around them. When you get a whole row of them, some of them idling; you’ve got trucks, big pieces of equipment and you’re out there in your little Prius wanting to go up to Milk River to get groceries, it can be very intimidating. Other people; we have a lot of retired farmers; it didn’t bother them that much. Had one guy just the other day say, “You’re going to testify be sure you tell ’em we were never blocked in, could always make it up there. Had to drive through the field a couple of times but we weren’t really blockaded.” So it depended on the person and how they could handle it. And it affected some people -- I have a friend who is a veteran of Afghanistan and she has PTSD. She had -- they had to leave town because it triggered her PTSD and she just couldn’t take it. They’re back now. Older people; had one lady who would -- if somebody drove her out to -- for a doctor’s appointment or something, she would curl up in a ball -- I wasn’t going to do this -- but just depends on the person; how they grew up, what their situations are. Some people it really bothered.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Did you hear any reports of intimidation of some of your resident -- residents by protestors?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: A couple, and you take it as -- you know, take everything with a grain of sand -- grain of sand; grain of salt. The -- had a couple of people tell me that they were coming back into Coutts and being stopped by protestors and saying -- they’d say to the guy, “Now, what do you think? Should we let these people through or not?” Or, “Should let this guy through?” And, you know, “Where do you think you’re going?” and that kind of thing. But nothing -- we had a situation where a neighbour -- someone decided it’d be funny to tell everybody that there were free showers at her house, so she had people showing up at the door, that kind of thing. But not a lot of -- there was no physical intimidation, and it was basically just the going through the gauntlet to get out of the village. Like I said, if you drove through and up the highway and through the ditch maybe, well, you could go, so...
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And lastly, I just wanted to ask you, was there any impact on emergency services or access to emergency services?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: For the most part, no. When it first happened, it was like when we had the RVs there; the entrances, they said they wouldn’t block it. You have to understand, we depend on the ambulance coverage from Milk River, the medical clinic there. We have a volunteer fire department, we have volunteer EMS, and you’d have to understand AHS to note that -- health services to know why we have an ambulance that we can’t use. But anyway, we have one. We cover -- our fire department that is a rural fire department that covers everything out in the surrounding area, specially to the east. There’s only that road at 501, which is the road that crosses the tracks to get out to you there. That was one of my major concerns, was that we had egress quickly in the event of an emergency. And then that we could get an ambulance in. The RCMP ran an ambulance down the highway to test that and the protestors were able to clear it through quickly, so it was handled. But for the first few hours, there wasn’t any awareness on the part of the people. I said more than once, I got the impression that the protestors -- Coutts was an afterthought. They wanted to plug the highway and, “Oh gee, there’s 250 people over here and we kind of affected them too.” So it took us a while to work that out, but -- now, after everybody was made aware, things were fairly good.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you so much. Those are my questions, ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: --- Mayor Willett.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning, Mayor Willett.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Good morning.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: My name is Andrea Gonsalves, and I’m one of the lawyers representing the Government of Canada in this Inquiry. Thank you for being here today. I just have a few questions for you. And I want to start by talking about the port of entry at Coutts. And I understand on the other side of the border is the town of Sweet Grass, yes?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Sweet Grass, yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah. That port of entry, you’ll agree with me, is of vital importance to not only the Coutts community, Milk River, the surrounding communities, but also the Province of Alberta and Canada as a whole?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: I understand that Highway 4 is the primary access to that port of entry, although there’s one sideroad that’s not suitable for commercial vehicles, right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And it’s the only designated commercial port of entry in all of Alberta?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: I -- yeah, it’s the only 24-hour port, yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Right. That port of entry allows for the cross-border transport of livestock, agricultural goods, and other imports and exports that are critical to Alberta’s supply chain and the economy; yes?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And you can see, I assume from, really, your front door, the constant flow of trucks that are carrying billions of dollars’ worth of goods north and south across that border.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah. Now, you’ve told us that you learned early on of plans to -- that there were plans in the works for protesters to engage in slow roll protests in the vicinity of the Coutts port of entry?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And those quickly evolved into plans to actually block the highway to the border.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And that would have really a two-fold impact on the people of Coutts, both their access north into Milk River and the amenities there; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: As well as south down across the border. And so I would expect this raised some alarms for you as Mayor of this village?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And you acted quickly to communicate to residents how they could best prepare themselves; right? You sent out that little notice.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes, I did.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah. It's COU00000001. I don't think we need to pull it out unless you want to look at it. But you were trying to best equip your residents for the unknown of what was going to come; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And that notice included advice like pretending that they live in a big city?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: What did you mean by that?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: With the risk of giving too much away, a lot of people don't lock their doors. You might have a car that you know so-and-so needs to borrow, you'll put the keys in the car. We've got a almost zero percent crime rate because of our location and because of the fact that CBSA people live there and the guy that you broke into might have a gun. So the -- just people get very comfortable with -- it's typical small town Alberta.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And there were folks coming in that nobody knew ---
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: --- and you were concerned that that might pose a safety and security risk to the people of Coutts?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yeah. It's -- like I told a lot of people, you're driving south getting ready to hit the border, you don't even know Coutts is there, and -- although we can watch and wave. The -- and if you've got a stranger in town word gets around. So, you know, there's a car going around and I don't know who it belongs to, and oh, that's so-and-so, they're visiting so-and-so, you know. The telegraph works very well. And all of a sudden we're going with -- the potential existed that we were going to have massive influx of people driving up and down the streets, and I just wanted everybody to be careful. "Don't let your kids to run across to the playground because somebody might be coming not looking for kids there. Everybody in town knows your kids there, but if they come in from out of town they don't." Just a heightened awareness, I guess, of your situation.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And another step you took in the early stages was to reach out to provincial -- the provincial government; yes?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.

speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: And just while that’s coming up; so on page 5 you stated that you did not receive the type of support you expected from the provincial and federal governments. So what kind of support did you expect from the federal government?
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: At that point, it seemed like we were not getting anywhere, and I was looking for somebody to do something to get the highway unblocked and get things happening again. So any kind of support would have been -- make them go away and make this end. I wasn’t in a position to say exactly who should do what, but somebody should appear to be doing something, and at this time it didn’t look like anybody was doing much.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And so I have the same question with respect to provincial government; what kind of support did you expect from the provincial government?
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: Same story. We had the -- as I mentioned before, an Act that was supposed to give unlimited powers, basically, to protect infrastructure and remedy this exact problem, and yet it appeared to me nothing was going on. Now, I’ve seen the situation reports since then and it showed that there was action in the background, but I wasn’t privy to that, so where I was sitting in my office looking out the window, I didn’t see anything happening.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. So now that you say that there’s things that you saw going on in the background, in your opinion is that statement still true, that you believe that the provincial government should have made better use of the Critical Infrastructure Act?
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And you had wanted Minister Sonya to speak with protestors?
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: It was not my suggestion. It was her suggestion. She thought that she could come and talk to people in the first day or two because she was getting feedback from the fact that there are truckers stuck. She wanted to come, and I don't know what she had planned to say, but it was her suggestion that she come down.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And you had said that the protestors were like herding cats?
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: The protestors were letting ---
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Were like herding cats, sorry, excuse me.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: Yeah, that's what Alex told me when -- the first time I made contact with the guys, the smugglers, he said at that time that it was like herd -- that's my expression, but that was the impression. He said he could get a group here and a group there and try and get them all together and they'd make a decision, then they'd walk out the door and forgot what they'd talked about. So he was very frustrated.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: So there was no definitive leader of the protest?
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: At that point, there didn't appear to be.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And I just have one point of clarification. So in your evidence with my friend Commission Counsel, you said that tractors lined up on the side of the road on the 14th. And I just want to clarify, that's so traffic could flow?
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: Oh, by then they were off the highway, and I think at that point, traffic was being held up in Milk River still, but there wasn't any really physical blockading going on, on the morning on the 15th, possibly on the evening of the 14th. I couldn't do 24-hour coverage. But, no, the tractors were all lined up. They were just getting ready to leave as a group, and so they pulled them all in -- actually pulled them into the village and down that street and lined them up along there, so they were out of the way.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And you're not sure if that was the evening of the 14th, or did that start the evening of the 14th where they were moving the tractors?
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: When I went down the morning of the 15th to see what was going on, they were all lined up down the street. That's all I know, and I don't know exactly when. Like I say, I wasn't sitting, watching them 24 hours a day, so I'm not sure when they moved.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. Perfect. Thank you, Mayor Willett. That's all my questions.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO

text_clean_combined: Thank you.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Next is the City of Windsor.
section_header: CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. HANA LAURA YAMAMOTO
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: --- CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MICHAEL FINLEY:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning ---
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Good morning.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: --- Mayor Willett. My name's Michael Finley. I represent the City of Windsor, which as I'm sure you're aware, is a fellow border municipality.
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And we heard today, Mayor Willett, you live just blocks away from the protest site and indeed the border; right?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: No matter where you are in Coutts, you're only blocks away, yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And that border crossing is an important link; true?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: It definitely is.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And I think you described it earlier as a lifeline and something with larger importance than just to the village of Coutts; is that fair?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And I guess perhaps I'm stating the obvious, sir, but fair to say that the village of Coutts doesn't have sufficient resources on its own to ensure the security of that border crossing?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Or, in fact, to deal with a blockade of the magnitude that you faced earlier this year?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: No, our police force, as you heard, is four or five officers stationed in Milk River.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: RCMP.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And so a situation like that requires more than a local response; is that fair?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Including because you noted earlier, provincial support?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And federal support too?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Yeah, well, that's RCMP, so it's provincial and federal.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And so that being so, would you agree that one might benefit from having a plan or at least a framework in advance to deal with situations like the one you experienced, even if they're not exactly the same, in future?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Sure, yeah. It would be nice. Dealing with hindsight is 20/20 but it would have been nice to have a plan, yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: I think you spoke about being caught flatfooted and building an airplane while it's flying. I guess we can agree you're sticking with that metaphor? It's probably better to have the plane assembled in advance before it takes to the air?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Yeah, if we're talking about police response, they had response for certain situations, but this was a situation that was unique, at the time, to anything they'd faced. And so I'm not going to be an apologist for the RCMP, but I think they were doing well under the circumstances. I don't think it's fair to say they had no plan. They would have had plans for demonstrations and so on, just nothing of this magnitude.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Right. And I suppose all I'm getting at is it's better in this type of circumstance, I hope you'll agree with me, when you have a multijurisdictional issue to deal with to have some plan in advance to address it?
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Well, thank you, sir. Those are all my questions.
speaker: MR. MICHAEL FINLEY

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Next are the Convoy Organizers.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: --- CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR. BRENDAN MILLER:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning, Mayor. For the record, Brendan Miller. I'm appearing as counsel for Freedom Corp., which represents the protestors that were in the City of Ottawa in January and February. How are you doing?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Good. How are you?
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Long flight. I love driving through Coutts.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: So beautiful part of the country. So if we could please bring up -- it's the document that my friends have already referred to from the federal government. It's the Canada document ending 8500 that was just up?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Apologies. Do you have the full doc ID?
speaker: THE CLERK

text_clean_combined: Yes, I do. It is PB.NSC.CAN.00008500. Okay. Can we please scroll to page 32? It's just loading still. There we go. Okay. So this is a document my friend put to you. It's a Power Point put together by the RCMP. And there you can see that they are doing what they refer to as media engagement and talking and listening to protesters, supporters and residents of Coutts. Did you witness any of that?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Not personally.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: I -- only on ---
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: --- line.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: But you ended up going and speaking to the protestors yourself too; didn't you?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Right. And I understand that when you did that, you ended up doing an interview with CTV and City News about that experience; do you remember that?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: I don't.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. Well, let me ask you if you remember saying this. I just want to put this -- this is a statement that's been attributed to you. "I wasn't negotiating or anything else. I was just there to find out if they were as bad as some people have said, and they're certainly not." Do you remember saying that?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Sounds like something I would say, yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And do you remember saying this about the protestors, "They're the same guys that I have for neighbours."
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: That was part of the uniqueness of this whole demonstration, yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Right. And you also said, "They're the guy that owns the farm up on the hill, the guy that hauls for local businesses." Remember saying that?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Probably did.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Right. And this situation, I understand, polarised your community. There was -- the community was essentially divided by half supporting, half against the truckers. Is that fair?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: As I said earlier, probably 70-30.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: On a good day, yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Right. And was that 70-30 in support or which one was in the 30 and 70?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: That would have been supporting the -- the protests.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Seventy (70) percent or 30 percent supporting the protest?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Seventy (70) percent.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. So the majority of your town.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Majority of the town, was the feeling I got.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And there was signs up and flags of all kinds that were on residences of your town’s property. Is that fair?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: A few, yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And can you tell me about some of the ones you saw and describe them? I know some of them were a bit vulgar, but if you’d like to.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Everybody has seen them. The Trudeau flags, the ---
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: The ones that say “F Trudeau”?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah, okay.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Some of the Gadsen flags, the “Don’t Treat on Me”. A lot of Canadian flags, many of them inverted, which I wholeheartedly do not approve of.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And those flags were in your own community.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Yeah. A lot of U.S. flags. Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And because you’re right on the border with Montana there; right? There is an intersect between the population in Montana and Coutts. Is that fair?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And can you explain, how long have you been in rural Alberta politics?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: In rural Alberta politics since I was elected to Council -- we had this discussion -- five years ago.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And what’s the vibe you get or the interactions you have with your residents with respect to their support or lack of support for the federal government as it currently is composed?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Well, I’ll quote my CAO, “Trudeau hates us”, and that’s basically -- you could talk to anybody here. There’s a great dislike for the federal government on a high percentage.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And what is these dislikes? What are they about? What are these people’s grievances in your residents and in that area?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Genetic. I don’t know how you -- I’ve lived in Alberta for half my life, which means a long time, and I’ve seen this “us versus them” thing grow, east versus west. I spend too much time on social media. But the feeling -- smarter minds than me have tried to figure it out. I really don’t understand the great dislike for the federal government.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: So there was -- I don’t know if you got the opportunity to watch -- did you watch the testimony of Ms. Tamara Lich in this proceeding because it was played out on TV?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: I saw some of it.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Did you -- do you remember when she said that a lot of Albertans feel that they don’t have a voice because the elections that are in -- resulting in the elections of MP and the federal executive are determined before they even vote and that they just don’t feel represented in Ottawa? Do you remember hearing that?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Yeah, it’s -- I think I heard that, yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Is that a general grievance that you’ve heard some of your constituents and that you’ve heard some of rural Albertans and other Albertans talk about?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: I believe so. Mr. Motz would probably disagree with the part that they’re not represented because he has represented us very well from that area. But I think the -- just talking -- that is a problem that anybody that has studied politics or government will agree with the fact that you’ve got a mass of population concentrated in the east and you don’t have in the west, and if you do just by votes, it’s very difficult to feel like you’re swaying anything when all of the election returns come in and by the time you’re voting, it’s already been decided. So I can understand it.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Are you aware that with respect to the protests in Ottawa it’s been reported that Albertans made up the -- essentially almost half of the individuals that were here?
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: I wasn’t aware of that, but it doesn’t surprise me.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. Next is the Democracy Fund, JCCF.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: --- CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR. ALAN HONNER:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Yes. Good morning, Commissioner. Good morning, Mayor.
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Good morning.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: My name is Alan Honner. I’m a lawyer at the Democracy Fund. We share status with the JCCF and with Citizens for Freedom. Mayor, I think you gave evidence earlier today that Coutts is the only 24-hour border crossing in Alberta? Did I understand that right?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And about 75 kilometres away from Coutts, there’s another border crossing at Del Bonita?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And do you know if the border crossing times at Del Bonita were extended during the times of the Coutts protest?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Yes, they were, I believe.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Can you tell us a little bit more about that, the hours of the days they were extended?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Oh, I can’t give you that without it in front of me, but I don’t believe it ever went 24 hours. I know that it was increased considerably. I believe I read a number somewhere that percentage-wise, they saw crossings go up 917 percent or something like that, so it was -- it would have had to have been open a lot more, but I don’t have the numbers.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: That’s fair. Thank you. I’m wondering, before the protestors left on the 15th and before the -- let me actually rephrase this. After the Emergencies Act was invoked, did you speak to any of the protestors before they left?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Not directly, no.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: But you told us about rumours on social media which referred to bank accounts being frozen. Were those -- were those social media accounts coming from the protestors?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And how do you know that?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Well, okay, I’m not going to say 100 percent. Somebody could have been faking it. But there were -- there were Facebook pages called “Coutts Convoy”, “Coutts Convoy Restart” -- I’m not going to name them all. But they were obviously followers or participants of the protest by the content that was posted, by things that they said, and...
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: So these -- these were social media sites where you could sign up and you could make posts regardless of whether or not you were at the protest.
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: So anybody could have posted those rumours on that site.
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Anybody could. They are -- they were moderated sites. They would have to get past the administrator, but I don’t know -- I didn’t put them up there.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. Whatever the case is, however, you’d agree with me that the reason why the protestors ultimately leave, what you call the straw that broke the camel’s back, was the discovery of the weapons and it was not the rumours of the -- about the Emergencies Act.
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: I think that’s correct. I saw an interview with Alex van Herk that he did the evening of the 14th. It’s on YouTube, where he explicitly said that it was the weapons. It wasn’t the Act because they’d heard about it, but they were prepared to stay until it -- you know, that’s in Ottawa, basically, is what his sympathies were.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And Alex van Herk was one of the spokespeople or one of the leading people at Coutts among the protestors.
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: That’s correct. He’s been charged along with Marco, so I’m not sure how much I’m supposed to talk about it, but.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: We’ll move on. My friend from the Government of Canada brought up the Critical Infrastructure Defence Act. And I understand you thought that the RCMP should have used that Act against the protestors.
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: I did. Part of that might have been my misunderstanding of what they were doing. As I said, I wasn’t privy to the situation reports that were coming out every day until I saw them the other night. So there was stuff going on and there possibly are even charges still waiting for people over that Act. So ---
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And ---
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Yeah, go ahead.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: I’m sorry to interrupt. I think maybe what -- would you agree with me that the RCMP may have exercised their jurisdiction under that Act or their discretion under that Act, had the protest not ended when it did?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: I think they were doing it even as -- like, I know that there were violation tickets and so on being issued and that there possibly are still charges coming. So the process maybe doesn’t move as quickly as I would like it to, but I believe they were working under that Act, yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And I just want to ask you about that Act. Is it your understanding that the Act prohibits the wilful obstruction of essential infrastructure, if that obstruction renders the infrastructure dangerous, useless, inoperative, or ineffective?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. And in your view, that was happening in Coutts because of the blockade?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And if somebody commits an offence under that Act, the police can arrest that person without a warrant? Is that right?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: I’m not sure about the without a warrant, but I know they can arrest them.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: But you would take it from me that the Act says that?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Sure.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: There are also fines under the Act?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And does it accord with your understanding that the fine for a first offence can be no less than $1,000 and can be as much as $10,000?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: I’ve heard that, yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And that a fine for a second offence or a third offence can be as high as $25,000?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Sure.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Do you know if any of the protestors at Coutts were driving company vehicles or were parking company vehicles?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: I don’t know for sure. There might have been some owner/operators there. I didn’t see any name brand company vehicles parked there.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: But some of those trucks could have been owned by corporations?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: It’s possible.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And it’s also, under the Critical Infrastructure Defence Act, someone can be fined -- a corporation can be fined a minimum of $10,000 for an offence and a maximum of $200,000? Did you know that?
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: I may have seen those numbers. I don’t know. I’ll take your word for it.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. Thank you very much. Those are my questions.
speaker: MR. ALAN HONNER

text_clean_combined: Okay. Thank you. Mayor Willett, do you want to add anything? We’re done the cross-examinations. I’m just going to ask for -- whether there’s any re-examination by the Commission Counsel. So I’ll let the re-examination go and then I’ll give you a chance to add anything, if you’d like.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: --- RE-EXAMINATION BY MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Yes. Oh. Yes, okay. I just have two brief questions for you. Just to clarify a point, when you were talking about your discussion with Mr. Evans about the arrests on the 14th, I think you kind of trailed off a bit under your breath and said something about the weapons were all fake. Something like that. is that something Mr. Evans told you?
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: I believe he mentioned that there was a rumour they had been planted, even at that early date. And then I know that YouTube video I saw of Mr. Van Herk, where he also said he didn’t believe that they were real, but they were going to -- that was the -- that was what was being said, so it was what happened. But yeah, to answer your question, that’s what was said.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: I just wanted to confirm, that was not your own assessment of the situation?
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: That was not my assessment, no.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Thank you.
speaker: MR. JEAN-SIMON SCHOENHOLZ

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. So that’s it. Do you want to add anything before you head back west?
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: It’s cold out there. How long can I talk? No, the situation that happened there, there were a lot of people that said that I was against the protest. And I wanted to make it perfectly clear, I was never against the protest. You have that freedom, that right to protest anytime you want, as long as you don’t break the law and interfere with my right to travel and so on. I mean, I -- in a way, I participated in their protest, because along with the other border mayors, we communicated with the Federal Government saying, “This is not right, to treat these guys, after the two years, as if they’ve suddenly become pariahs or something.” So the biggest problem that I had, and I still have, understanding blocking that highway, was who you thought you were damaging. You were damaging your neighbours. I had stock movers who couldn’t move cattle because it was blocked. That’s a whole part of a chain. People grow their stock, they plan for a particular date to deliver it to the feedlot, so they’ve got feed for X number of days. Now that’s backed up. Now they’ve got to try and find feed. Well, gee, the feed comes from the other side of the border. They didn’t take into consideration the fact that, yes, they made a big splash, but they were hurting the very people that they figured they were helping by getting the mandates off. We’re a very agricultural area. I mentioned that I’m the chair of a regional economic development initiative. Our whole emphasis is on helping to establish that Canada trade corridor and the food corridor with all of the potatoes, and sugar beets, and pulses, and all of those products. That’s our main emphasis. And when you cut -- you stand there with your foot on my throat and say, “You’re not going to go through here anymore,” and what you’re doing is you’re actually choking the livelihood of all your friends and neighbours. And even if they sympathise with you, when they go to the grocery store and there’s no fresh produce there because it’s on the other side of the border, it’s something to consider. So that was the main thing. And when the protest turned to an illegal blockade, they lost my support. And that’s it. And I did what I did as far as the village goes because I’m responsible for those people. And I’ll try and get through without breaking down here this time, but there were people -- it was literally - - people were literally physically frozen and not able to go through that blockade. And since everything is on the other side, it was a tough situation. But we’re not here to argue about that anyway. The feeling that I got, to be truthful, is -- which I have to be, right, is that the federal action had very little to do with the resolution of the blockade there. I think it was the police action, the finding of the undesirable element. I know that happened. I have -- I've talked to neighbours who saw the actual police action that night. It wasn't a carrying in weapons and planning them. It was a raid with SWAT-type vehicles. We had a field hospital set up at the fire hall and that kind of thing. So it was a very serious -- very serious situation. So -- and one last thing. I'm very complimentary of the police. The RCMP handled themselves very well. And I'm glad it's over. It's -- and I thank you for that opportunity. I'd ---
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Well, that's fine. We're here to get at the bottom of what happened, not only in Coutts, but across. Can I just ask you one thing following up on you're all in favour of protests, and you'd mentioned about the land that had been set up to continue protesting and it wasn't used until after the blockade was cleared.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Did I hear you correctly?
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And they continued to protest there for some time you said?
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Weeks. Yeah, I don't know the exact number.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: And do you know if it was the same group that had blockaded that continued to protest there?
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I believe that most of that was people who had showed up for the secondary encampment and they just moved off the road because they had no where else to go.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. Well, thank you very much for coming. It's appreciated. Your evidence was appreciated. You're free to go back to the cold.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Well, thanks, I think.
speaker: MAYOR JIMMY WILLETT

text_clean_combined: Okay. So we're going to take the morning adjournment, the morning break, and come back with a new witness, so we'll take 15 minutes.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: The Commission is in recess for 15 minutes. La Commission levée pour 15 minutes.
speaker: THE REGISTRAR

speaker: DSG MARIO Di TOMMASO

text_clean_combined: --- orienting yourself in time I think is probably advisable. So, yes, just to -- to start over, your position, of course, is Deputy Solicitor General for Ontario; correct?
speaker: MR. GABRIEL POLIQUIN

text_clean_combined: Yes.

text_clean_combined: Okay. And are you the only Deputy Solicitor General?
